importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: China expanded export controls on 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals and certain refining equipment, effective December 1, in response to US trade restrictions.
Trump announced a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, and accused China of 'trade hostility'.
Trump and Xi are expected to meet in South Korea during the APEC summit, but the trade dispute has created uncertainty about the meeting’s continuation.
Former President Joe Biden tightened controls on US semiconductor exports to China, restricting access to advanced chip-making tools and technology.
Biden restricted US exports of advanced computer chips to China, aiming to limit military and AI applications in China.
Biden introduced restrictions on Chinese access to US semiconductors and chip-making tools, part of broader strategic semiconductor controls.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2024 to 2025 marks ongoing strategic competition between the US and China in trade, technology, and export controls, especially regarding rare earths and semiconductors.
A sustained period of US export control actions and Chinese countermeasures, including rare earth restrictions and semiconductor bans, reflects a broader strategic economic rivalry.

keyTakeAways: Trump's threat of a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, announced on October 10, 2025, signals a sharp escalation in US-China trade tensions, potentially reigniting a trade war months after a truce was agreed upon.

China responded with expanded export controls on rare earth metals and refining equipment, citing national security concerns and accusing the US of discriminatory trade practices and overreach in export controls.

Rare earth minerals are critical for technologies such as electric vehicles, smartphones, semiconductors, and military hardware—making them a strategic and high-value commodity in the global supply chain.

The US and China have a long history of tit-for-tat tariffs, including a 2018-2024 trade war that peaked with 145% and 125% tariffs before being reduced to 30% and 10%, with periodic truces and renewed threats.

Both nations are weaponizing economic interdependence, with each side using national security justifications to justify export controls and trade restrictions, raising concerns about a broader 'security economy' conflict.
China's actions are seen as pre-meeting strategy to gain leverage in negotiations with Trump before their expected meeting in South Korea in October 2025.

Experts note that while China appears more strategically organized, the US has greater economic resilience due to its large domestic market and strong consumer demand, though lower-income households are disproportionately affected by inflation.
The US and China are both retaining escalation tools, indicating a standoff where neither side is willing to back down, and the outcome will depend on market reactions and global economic stability.
The dispute highlights a growing trend of great power competition, where trade and technology are being used as instruments of strategic influence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores the escalating trade conflict between the United States and China, centered on Trump’s threat of a 100% tariff on Chinese goods and China’s retaliatory export controls on rare earth minerals. This follows a long history of tit-for-tat tariffs and export restrictions, including those targeting Huawei and TikTok, and reflects a broader strategic economic rivalry. Both nations are using national security arguments to justify trade actions, with experts noting that China has adopted a more strategic and coordinated approach, while the US has shown greater economic resilience. The situation is set against the backdrop of an expected meeting between Trump and Xi in South Korea, where the tension may influence diplomatic outcomes. Analysts suggest that neither side is willing to back down, and the outcome will depend on market stability and global economic responses.
title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
